title: Class explores cover crops in ag systems

subtasks: Students planted various combinations of cover crops
Victor Halmos planted sorghum-sudan grass, oilseed radish, and hairy vetch
Suzanne Deeb planted hairy vetch, vestard, and buckwheat
Observing competition between cover crops (e.g., hairy vetch vs. tillage radish; other combinations)
Students collected data on cover crop performance
Analyzing competition dynamics between different cover crops
College students from seven US universities participated
Course co-taught by UK weed scientist Erin Harimoto and instructors from other schools
In-person exercises combined with virtual discussions via Zoom

tasks.task: Studying cover crops' benefits and challenges
subtasks: Examining ways to maximize cover crop benefits while minimizing negatives
Addressing economic incentives and long-term benefits vs. short-term costs

tasks.task: Soil health assessment using "soil your undies" method
subtasks: Participants buried specific brand underwear in fields under different management practices
Evaluating soil microbial activity through decomposition rates of buried underwear

tasks.task: Studying cover crop benefits and challenges
Assessing soil health using the "soil your undies" method
Collecting data on cover crop performance
Then the soil health assessment via "soil your undies" is another MAINTASK.
Planting cover crop mixtures (covering sowing of specific combinations)
Collecting samples and data (which includes observations, measurements, etc.)
Assessing soil health (including the "soil your undies" method).
Participating in hybrid class (for those students from other universities)
Therefore, three MAINTASKs, each with subtasks.

subtasks: Analyzing soil microbial activity through decomposition rates (soil your undies method)
